Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story:
I walked through the door just as my phone buzzed with a reminder: the final team meeting was in ten minutes. My wife was sitting on the couch, scrolling through her phone, but I could tell something was off. She looked up and sighed, “Work was a bit much today. Nothing huge, just… exhausting.” I knew she wanted me to sit with her, listen, maybe offer a hug or a few words to help her unwind. That’s what I always try to do—be present, supportive, her safe place after a long day.

But my mind was already racing through the agenda for the meeting. This was the last chance to voice concerns before the project plan was set in stone. My team expected me to be there, to contribute, to show I cared about our work as much as they did. I could feel the pressure building in my chest, torn between the warmth of the living room and the cold glow of my laptop screen. I wanted to be the husband she needed, but I also couldn’t let my colleagues down. I stood there, caught in the hallway, heart pounding, unsure which way to turn.
